newsitem.title: POLAND: Polish Gdansk refinery Jan-Aug net plunges 46 pct.
newsitem.headline: Polish Gdansk refinery Jan-Aug net plunges 46 pct.

text.p: Net profit for Gdansk refinery, Poland's second biggest, fell 46 percent in Jan-Aug against the same period last year to 51.4 million zlotys, the head of the refinery's finance department said on Wednesday.
Stanislaw Pokojski told Reuters that the company's gross profit in that period was 65.9 million zlotys, also 46 percent lower than in the same period last year.
He said the refinery's costs grew 21 percent to 1.978 billion zlotys.
"The refinery's profit plunged because prices of oil on world markets have soared while the government's policy of keeping domestic prices flat have reduced the refinery's profits," Pokojski said.

Pokojski said however, the firm's smaller earnings would not affect Gdansk's financing arragement with Merrill Lynch, which is the organiser of a fully-guaranteed $100 million five-year loan for the refinery's modernisation.
The whole modernisation programme, to be completed until 1999, will cost $400 million.
Pokojski said the Merrill Lynch loan accounted for 25 percent of funds needed for the programme and that another 25 percent the refinery would seek to raise from a consortium of Polish banks.

He said the firm asked the state-owned commercial Bank Handlowy SA, Bank Pekao SA, PKO BP and the private Bank Gdanski to organise such a consortium, hoping the agreement could be signed by the end of November.
Pokojski said the refinery would raise the remaining funds by issuing three-year commercial papers late next year.
